<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>The importance of free software to science</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1023299/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1023299/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jake</dc:creator>
			<description>Free software plays a critical role in science, both in research and in
disseminating it. Aspects of software freedom are directly relevant to
simulation, analysis, document preparation and preservation, security,
reproducibility, and usability. Free software brings practical and specific
advantages, beyond just its ideological roots, to science, while
proprietary software comes with equally specific risks.  As a practicing
scientist, I would like to help others—scientists or not—see the benefits
from free software in science.
</description>

			<description>The <a

realtime model</a>, which is implemented in the Linux kernel, can ensure
that a realtime process obtains the CPU time it needs to get its job done.
It can be less effective, though, when there are multiple realtime
processes competing for the available CPU resources.  The <a
href="https://lwn.net/ml/all/20250605071412.139240-1-yurand2000@gmail.com">hierarchical
constant bandwidth server</a> patch series, posted by Yuri Andriaccio with
work by Luca Abeni, Alessio Balsini, and Andrea Parri, is a modification to

multiple realtime tasks in a deterministic and correct manner.

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>A parallel path for GPU restore in CRIU</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1024747/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1024747/</guid>
			<dc:creator>daroc</dc:creator>
			<description><p> The fundamental concept of checkpoint/restore is elegant: capture a
process's state and resurrect it later, perhaps elsewhere. Checkpointing
meticulously records a process's memory, open files, CPU state, and more into a
snapshot. Restoration then reconstructs the process from this state. This
established technique faces new challenges with GPU-accelerated applications,
where low-latency restoration is crucial for
<a href='https://criu.org/Usage_scenarios#Fault-tolerant_systems'>fault
tolerance</a>, live migration, and
fast startups. Recently, the restore process for AMD GPUs has been redesigned to
eliminate substantial bottlenecks. </p>
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 26 Jun 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Libxml2's "no security embargoes" policy</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1025971/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1025971/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jzb</dc:creator>
			<description><p><a
href="https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/#libxml2">Libxml2</a>, an
XML parser and toolkit, is an almost perfect example of the successes
and failures of the open-source movement. In the 25 years since its
first release, it has been widely adopted by open-source projects, for
use in commercial software, and for government use. It also
illustrates that while many organizations love using open-source software,
far fewer have yet to see value in helping to sustain it. That has led
libxml2's current maintainer to reject security embargoes and sparked
a discussion about maintenance terms for free and open-source
projects.</p>
</description>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Getting extensions to work with free-threaded Python</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1025893/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1025893/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jake</dc:creator>
			<description>One of the biggest changes to come to the Python world is the <a
href="https://lwn.net/Articles/947138/">addition of the free-threading
interpreter</a>, which eliminates the <a
href="https://docs.python.org/3/glossary.html#term-global-interpreter-lock">global
interpreter lock</a> (GIL) that kept the interpreter thread-safe, but also
serialized multi-threaded Python code.  Over the years, the GIL has been a
source of complaints about the scalability of Python code using
threads, so many developers have been looking forward to the change, which
has been an experimental feature since <a
href="https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-3130/">Python 3.13
was released</a> in October 2024.  Making the free-threaded version work
with the rest of the Python ecosystem, especially native extensions, is an
ongoing effort, however; Nathan Goldbaum and Lysandros Nikolaou spoke at <a
href="https://us.pycon.org/2025/">PyCon US 2025</a> about those efforts.
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 03 Jul 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Accessing new kernel features from Python</title>

			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1026749/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jake</dc:creator>
			<description>Every release of the Linux kernel has lots of new features, many of which
are accessible from user space.  Usually, though, the GNU C Library (glibc)
and tools that access the Linux user-space API lag behind the kernel
releases.  Geoffrey Thomas showed how Python programs can access these new
kernel features as soon as the kernel is released in his "What's New in the
Linux Kernel... from Python" talk at
<a
href="https://us.pycon.org/2025/">PyCon US 2025</a>.  While he had two
examples of accessing new kernel features, the real goal of the talk was to
demonstrate <i>how</i> to go about connecting Python to
the Linux kernel.

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Yet another way to configure transparent huge pages</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1025629/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1025629/</guid>
			<dc:creator>daroc</dc:creator>
			<description><p>
<a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/423584/">
Transparent huge pages</a> (THPs) are, theoretically, supposed to allow processes to
benefit from larger page sizes without changes to their code. This does work,
but the performance impacts from THPs are not always a benefit, so system
administrators with specific knowledge of their workloads may want the ability
to fine-tune THPs to the application. On May&#160;15, Usama Arif
<a href="https://lwn.net/ml/all/20250515133519.2779639-1-usamaarif642@gmail.com/">
shared</a> a patch set that would add a
<a href="https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/prctl.2.html">
<tt>prctl()</tt></a> option for setting THP defaults for a process; that patch
set has sparked discussion about whether such a setting is a good fit for
<tt>prctl()</tt>, and what alternative designs may work instead.
</p>
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 10 Jul 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Reinventing the Python wheel</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1028299/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1028299/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jake</dc:creator>
			<description>It is no secret that the Python packaging world is at something of a
crossroads; there have been debates and discussions about the packaging
landscape that started long before our <a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/924104/">2023
series</a> describing some of the difficulties.  There has been progress
since then—and incremental improvements all along, in truth—but a new
initiative is looking to overhaul packaging for the language.  At <a
href="https://us.pycon.org/2025/">PyCon US 2025</a>, Barry Warsaw and
Jonathan Dekhtiar gave a presentation on the <a
href="https://wheelnext.dev/">WheelNext project</a>, which is a community
effort that aims to improve the experience for users and providers of Python
packages while also working with toolmakers and other parts of the
ecosystem to "<q>reinvent the wheel</q>".  While the project's name refers
to Python's <a
href="https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/binary-distribution-format/">wheel</a>
binary distribution format, its goals stretch much further than simply the
format.
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 17 Jul 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Toward the unification of kselftests and KUnit</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1029077/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1029077/</guid>
			<dc:creator>corbet</dc:creator>
			<description>The kernel project, for many years, lacked a formal testing setup; it was
often joked that testing was the project's main reason for keeping users
around.  While many types of kernel testing can only be done in the
presence of specific hardware, there are other parts of the kernel
that could be more widely tested.  Over time, though, the kernel has gained
two separate testing frameworks and a growing body of automated tests to go
with them.  These two frameworks — kselftests and KUnit — take different
approaches to the testing problem; now <a
href="https://lwn.net/ml/all/20250626-kunit-kselftests-v4-0-48760534fef5@linutronix.de">this
patch series</a> from Thomas Weißschuh aims to bring them together.
</description>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Linux and Secure Boot certificate expiration</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1029767/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1029767/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jake</dc:creator>
			<description>Linux users who have <a
href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFI#Secure_Boot">Secure Boot</a>
enabled on their systems knowingly or unknowingly rely on a key from
Microsoft that is set to expire in September.  After that point, Microsoft
will no longer use that key to sign the <a
href="https://github.com/rhboot/shim#shim-a-first-stage-uefi-bootloader">shim</a>
first-stage UEFI bootloader that is used by Linux distributions to boot the
kernel with Secure Boot.  But the replacement key, which has been available
since 2023, may not be installed on many systems; worse yet, it may require
the hardware vendor to issue an update for the system firmware, which may
or may not happen.  It seems that the vast majority of systems will not be
lost in the shuffle, but it may require extra work from distributors and
users.
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 24 Jul 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Fedora SIG changes Python packaging strategy</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1029354/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1029354/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jzb</dc:creator>
			<description><p>Fedora's <a
href="https://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/neurofedora/overview/">NeuroFedora
special-interest group</a> (SIG) is considering a change of strategy
when it comes to packaging Python modules. The SIG, which consists of
three active members, is struggling to keep up with maintaining the
<a href="https://pagure.io/neuro-sig/NeuroFedora/blob/main/f/package-list/list.txt">hundreds of packages</a> that it has taken on. What's more, it's not
clear that the majority of packages are even being consumed by Fedora
users; the group is trying to determine the right strategy to meet its
goals and shed unnecessary work. If its new packaging strategy is
successful, it may point the way to a more sustainable model for Linux
distributions to provide value to users without trying to package
everything under the sun.</p>
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 24 Jul 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Deep immutability for Python</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1030291/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1030291/</guid>
			<dc:creator>daroc</dc:creator>
			<description><p>
Python has recently seen a number of experiments to improve its parallel
performance, including exposing
<a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/820424/">
subinterpreters</a> as part of the standard library. These allow
separate threads within the same Python process to run simultaneously, as long
as any data sent between them is copied, rather than shared.
<a href="https://pep-previews--4468.org.readthedocs.build/pep-0795/">
PEP&#160;795</a> ("Deep Immutability in Python")
seeks to make efficient sharing of data between subinterpreters possible by
allowing Python objects to be "frozen", so that they can be accessed from
multiple subinterpreters without copying or synchronization.
That task is more difficult than it
seems, and the PEP prompted a good deal of skepticism from the Python community.
</p>
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 31 Jul 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Extending run-time verification for the kernel</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1030685/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1030685/</guid>
			<dc:creator>daroc</dc:creator>
			<description><p>
There are a lot of things people expect the Linux kernel to do correctly. Some
of these are checked by testing or static analysis; a few are ensured by
run-time verification: checking a live property of a running Linux system. For
example, the scheduler has a handful of different correctness properties that
can be
checked in this way.
Nam Cao posted a
<a href="https://lwn.net/ml/all/cover.1751634289.git.namcao@linutronix.de/">
patch series</a> that aims to extend the kinds of properties that the kernel's
<a href="https://docs.kernel.org/trace/rv/runtime-verification.html">run-time
verification system</a> can check, by adding support for
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_temporal_logic">
linear temporal logic</a> (LTL). The patch set has seen eleven revisions since the
<a href="https://lwn.net/ml/all/cover.1741708239.git.namcao@linutronix.de/">
first version</a> in March&#160;2025, and recently made it into the linux-next
tree, from where it seems likely to reach the mainline kernel soon.
</p>
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 07 Aug 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>A proxy-execution baby step</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1030842/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1030842/</guid>
			<dc:creator>corbet</dc:creator>
			<description>Priority inversion comes about when a low-priority task holds a resource
that is also needed by a high-priority task, preventing the latter from
running.  This problem is made much worse if the low-priority task is
unable to gain access to the CPU and, as a result, cannot complete its work
and free the resources it holds.  Proxy execution is a potential solution
to this problem, but it is a complex solution that has been under
development for several years; LWN first <a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/820575/">looked
at it</a> in 2020.  The 6.17 kernel is likely to contain an important step
forward for this long-running project.
</description>

		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Possible paths for signing BPF programs</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1031854/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1031854/</guid>
			<dc:creator>daroc</dc:creator>
			<description><p>
BPF programs are loaded directly into the kernel.
Even though the verifier protects the kernel from certain kinds of
misbehavior in BPF programs, some people are still justifiably concerned about
adding unsigned code to their kernel. A fully correct BPF program can still be
used to expose sensitive data, for example.
To remedy this, Blaise Boscaccy and KP Singh
have both shared patch sets that add ways to verify cryptographic
signatures of BPF programs, allowing users to configure their kernels to load
only pre-approved BPF programs. This work follows on from the
<a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/1017549/">
discussion</a> at the
Linux Storage, Filesystem, Memory-Management, and BPF Summit (LSFMM+BPF)
in April and Boscaccy's
<a href="https://lwn.net/ml/all/20250502184421.1424368-1-bboscaccy@linux.microsoft.com/">
earlier proposal</a> of a Linux Security Module (LSM) to accomplish the same goal.
There are
still some fundamental disagreements over the best approach to signing BPF
programs, however.
</p>
</description>

		</item>

			<description>Ken Jin welcomed <a

his talk entitled "Building a new tail-calling interpreter for Python", but
noted that the title really should be: "Measuring the performance of
compilers and interpreters is really hard".  Jin's efforts <a
href="https://lwn.net/Articles/1010905/">to switch the CPython interpreter to use tail calls</a>,
which can be optimized as regular jumps,
initially seemed to produce an almost miraculous performance improvement.
As his modified title suggests, the <a
href="https://blog.nelhage.com/post/cpython-tail-call/">actual improvement
was rather smaller</a>; there is still some performance improvement and
there are other benefits from the change.

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>The tangled web of XSLT browser support</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1034560/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1034560/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jzb</dc:creator>
			<description><p>The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XSLT">Extensible
Stylesheet Language Transformations</a> (XSLT) language is used by web
browsers to style XML content to make it easily readable; XSLT is part of the
<a href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/">HTML living
standard</a> that is maintained by the <a
href="https://whatwg.org/">Web Hypertext Application Technology
Working Group</a> (WHATWG). Only a small fraction of web sites serve
content that requires web browsers to support XSLT, in part because
major browser implementations have neglected the technology over the past 25
years. Now, it seems, they would like to rid themselves of it
entirely. A <a href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/435623334">plan</a>
to disable XSLT in <a href="https://www.chromium.org/blink/">Blink</a> (Chrome's rendering engine) and a <a
href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/11563">pull request</a> by
a Google Chrome developer to remove mentions of the specification from
the HTML standard have been met with opposition, but arguments in
favor of XSLT have proven ineffective.</p>
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 04 Sep 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Shadow-stack control in clone3()</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1034442/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1034442/</guid>
			<dc:creator>corbet</dc:creator>
			<description>Shadow stacks are a control-flow-integrity feature designed to defend
against exploits that manipulate a thread's call stack.  The kernel first
<a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/926649/">gained support for hardware-implemented shadow
stacks</a>, for the x86 architecture, in the 6.6 release; 64-bit Arm
support followed in 6.13.  This feature does not give user space much
control over the allocation of shadow stacks for new threads, though; a <a
href="https://lwn.net/ml/all/20250819-clone3-shadow-stack-v19-0-bc957075479b@kernel.org">patch
series</a> from Mark Brown may, after many attempts, finally be about
to change that situation.
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 04 Sep 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Tracking trust with Rust in the kernel</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1034603/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1034603/</guid>
			<dc:creator>daroc</dc:creator>
			<description><p>
The Linux kernel has to handle many different sources of data that should not
be trusted: user space, network connections, and removable storage, to name a
few. The kernel has to remain secure even if one of these sends garbled (or
malicious) data. Benno Lossin has been working on an API for kernel Rust code
that makes it harder to accidentally make decisions based on data from user space. That work
is now on its
<a href="https://lwn.net/ml/all/20250814124424.516191-1-lossin@kernel.org/">
fourth revision</a>, and Lossin has asked kernel developers to experiment with
it and see where problems remain, making this a good time to look at the proposed API.
</p>
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 11 Sep 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">

			<dc:creator>daroc</dc:creator>
			<description><p>
There are a large number of ways to configure the 6.16
Linux kernel. It has 32,468 different configuration options on x86_64,
and a comparable number for other platforms. Exploring the ways the kernel can
be configured is sufficiently difficult that it requires specialized tools.
These show the
<a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/1034812/">

what does it mean for testing?

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Canceling asynchronous Rust</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1036924/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1036924/</guid>
			<dc:creator>daroc</dc:creator>
			<description><p>
Asynchronous Rust code has what Rain Paharia calls a "<q>universal cancellation
protocol</q>", meaning that any asynchronous code can be interrupted in the same
way. They claim
that this is both a useful feature when used deliberately, and a source of
errors when done by accident. They presented
about this problem at
<a href="https://rustconf.com/">
RustConf&#160;2025</a>, offering a handful of techniques to avoid introducing bugs into
asynchronous Rust code.
</p>
</description>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">

			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1037974/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jake</dc:creator>
			<description>The <a
href="https://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/research/security/ctsrd/cheri/">Capability
Hardware Enhanced RISC Instructions</a> (CHERI) project is a rethinking of
computer architecture in order to improve system security.  Carl Shaw gave
a presentation at
<a
href="https://events.linuxfoundation.org/linux-security-summit-europe/">Linux
Security Summit Europe</a> (LSS EU) about CHERI and the efforts to get
Linux running on it.  He introduced <a
href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capability-based_security">capabilities</a>,
which are a mechanism for access control, and outlined their
history, which goes back many decades at this point, then looked more
specifically at the CHERI project and what it will take to apply the
<a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/909265/">security constraints of capabilities</a> to an operating system like Linux.
</description>

		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Upcoming Rust language features for kernel development</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1039073/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1039073/</guid>
			<dc:creator>daroc</dc:creator>
			<description><p>
The
<a href="https://rust-for-linux.com/">
Rust for Linux</a> project has been good for Rust, Tyler Mandry, one of the
co-leads of Rust's language-design team, said. He
gave a talk at
<a href="https://kangrejos.com/">
Kangrejos&#160;2025</a> covering upcoming Rust language features and thanking
the Rust for Linux developers for helping drive them forward. Afterward, Benno Lossin and Xiangfei Ding
went into more detail about their work on the three most important language
features for kernel development: field projections, in-place initialization, and arbitrary self types.

talk he gave <a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/993484/">last year</a> about the

			<description><p>

that need to handle interrupts: interrupt-aware spinlocks. Most drivers will
need to communicate information from interrupt handlers to main driver code, and
this exchange is frequently synchronized with the use of spinlocks. While his
first attempts ran into problems, Feng's ultimate solution could help prevent bugs
in C code as well, by tracking the number of nested scopes that have disabled
interrupts. The <a href="https://lwn.net/ml/all/20251013155205.2004838-1-lyude@redhat.com/">

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>DebugFS on Rust</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1041095/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1041095/</guid>
			<dc:creator>daroc</dc:creator>
			<description><p>
<a href="https://docs.kernel.org/filesystems/debugfs.html">
DebugFS</a> is the kernel's anything-goes, no-rules interface: whenever a kernel
developer needs quick access to internal details of the kernel to debug a
problem, or to implement an experimental control interface,
they can expose them via DebugFS. This is possible because DebugFS is not subject
to the normal rules for user-space-interface stability, nor to the rules about
exposing sensitive kernel information. Supporting DebugFS in Rust drivers is an
important step toward being able to debug real drivers on real hardware. Matthew
Maurer spoke at
<a href="https://kangrejos.com/">
Kangrejos&#160;2025</a> about his recently merged
<a href="https://lwn.net/ml/all/20250904-debugfs-rust-v11-0-7d12a165685a@google.com/">
DebugFS bindings for Rust</a>.
</p>
</description>

			<dc:creator>jake</dc:creator>
			<description>A new class of attacks on Android phones, called "<a
href="https://www.pixnapping.com/">Pixnapping</a>", was announced on
October 13.  It allows a malicious app to gather output rendered in a
victim app, pixel-by-pixel, by exploiting a GPU side-channel.  Depending on
what the victim app displays, anything from sensitive email and chats to
two-factor authentication (2FA) codes could be captured—and shipped off to
an attacker's site.

			<description><p>Linux has many security features and tools that have evolved over

href="https://all-systems-go.io/">All Systems Go!</a> conference held

systemd; however, Poettering said that he does have a vision for how
all of the security-related pieces of systemd are meant to fit

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Another Fedora Flatpak discussion</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1045247/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1045247/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jzb</dc:creator>
			<description><p>Many distributions provide support out of the proverbial box for
Flatpak packages, but Fedora is unusual in that it also provides, and
defaults, to its own repository of Fedora-built Flatpaks. This has been
a source of confusion for Fedora users, who expect to get the Flatpak
built by the original developers and hosted on <a
href="https://flathub.org/en">Flathub</a>. It has also been a source
of conflict with upstream projects, because users complain of bugs in
Flatpak packages they are not responsible for. The situation has also frustrated some
Fedora developers, who would prefer to put Flathub's offerings
first. A new complaint that Fedora has apparently used <a
href="https://docs.flatpak.org/en/latest/manifests.html#manifests">manifests</a>
from Flathub to build the packages for Fedora—without giving credit to
the original authors&mdash;has spurred discussions about Fedora's
Flatpaks once again. While no concrete changes are on the table, yet,
there may be some movement toward addressing persistent complaints.</p>
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>The intersection of unstable pages and direct I/O</title>

			<description>Longtime LWN readers will have encountered the concept of "stable pages"
before; it was first <a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/429295/">covered here</a> nearly
15&#160;years ago.  For the most part, the problem that stable pages were
meant to solve — preventing errors when user space modifies a buffer that
is under <span class="nobreak">I/O</span> — has been dealt with.  But
recent discussions show that there is one area where problems remain:
direct <span class="nobreak">I/O</span>.  There is some disagreement,

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Protecting privacy with Tails</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1044979/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1044979/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jzb</dc:creator>
			<description><p><a href="https://tails.net/">Tails</a> is an unusual Linux
distribution developed by the <a
href="https://www.torproject.org/about/history/">Tor Project</a>; it
is designed to help users work around internet censorship and avoid
surveillance. It is a "portable" operating system that is meant to be
run from a USB stick or ISO image and to leave no trace on the
computer it was run on. Tails routes connections to the internet over
the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tor_(network)">Tor
network</a> and includes a selection of applications and tools
suited to working with sensitive documents, communicating securely,
and preserving users' anonymity. The tradeoff, of course, is that
Tails is less convenient and requires users to learn a new set of
tools to avoid compromising their own security and anonymity. <a 
href="https://tails.net/news/version_7.1/">Tails&#160;7.1</a> was
released in October, and it seemed like as good a time as any to take
it for a spin.</p>
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
			<title>Just: a command runner</title>
			<link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1047715/</link>
			<guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1047715/</guid>
			<dc:creator>jzb</dc:creator>
			<description><p>Over time, many Linux users wind up with a collection of aliases,
shell scripts, and makefiles to run simple commands (or a series of
commands) that are often used, but challenging to remember and
annoying to type out at length. The <a
href="https://just.systems/"><tt>just</tt></a> command runner is a
Rust-based utility that just does one thing and does it well: it reads
recipes from a text file (aptly called a "justfile"), and runs the
commands from an invoked recipe. Rather than accumulating a library
of one-off shell scripts over time, <tt>just</tt> provides a cross-platform tool
with a framework and well-documented syntax for collecting and
documenting tasks that makes it useful for solo users and
collaborative projects.</p>
</description>
			<pubDate>Thu, 11 Dec 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		</item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">

        <guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1050174/</guid>
        <dc:creator>corbet</dc:creator>
        <description>The ability to write kernel code in Rust was explicitly added as an
experiment — if things did not go well, Rust would be removed again.  At
the 2025 Maintainers Summit, a session was held to evaluate the state of
that experiment, and to decide whether the time had come to declare the
result to be a success.  The (arguably unsurprising) conclusion was that
the experiment is indeed a success, but there were some interesting points
made along the way.
</description>

        </item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
        <title>Best practices for linux-next</title>
        <link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1050027/</link>
        <guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1050027/</guid>
        <dc:creator>corbet</dc:creator>
        <description>One of the key components in the kernel's development process is the
linux-next repository.  Every day, a large number of branches, each
containing commits intended for the next kernel development cycle, is
pulled into linux-next and integrated.  If there are conflicts between
branches, the linux-next process will reveal them.  In theory, many other
types of problems can be found as well.  Some developers feel that
linux-next does not work as well as it could, though.  At the 2025
Maintainers Summit, Mark Brown, who helps to keep linux-next going, led a
session on how it could be made to work more effectively.
</description>
        <pubDate>Thu, 25 Dec 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
        </item>

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">

<item xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">
        <title>Mix and match Linux distributions with Distrobox</title>
        <link>https://lwn.net/Articles/1049423/</link>
        <guid>https://lwn.net/Articles/1049423/</guid>
        <dc:creator>jzb</dc:creator>
        <description><p>Linux containers have made it reasonably easy to develop, distribute, and
deploy server applications along with all the distribution dependencies that they
need. For example, anyone can deploy and run a Debian-based <a
href="https://hub.docker.com/_/postgres">PostgreSQL container</a> 
on a Fedora&#160;Linux host. <a
href="https://distrobox.it/">Distrobox</a> is a project that is designed to
bring the cross-distribution compatibility to the desktop and allow users to
mix-and-match Linux distributions without fussing with dual-booting, virtual
machines, or multiple computers. It is an ideal way to install
additional software on image-based systems, such as Fedora's <a
href="https://fedoraproject.org/atomic-desktops/">Atomic Desktops</a>
or <a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/1046228/">Bazzite</a>, and also
provides a convenient way to move a development environment or
favorite applications to a new system.</p>
</description>
        <pubDate>Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
        </item>
